docs.lead_paragraph: This week, Dr. John Mulhall, director of the Male Sexual and Reproductive Medicine Program at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York, has been taking questions on the Well blog about what to expect following treatment for prostate cancer. Today, Dr. Mulhall, author of Saving Your Sex Life: A Guide for Men With Prostate Cancer, answers questions about screening methods, alternative remedies, penile implants and testosterone supplements.
docs.abstract: Dr. John Mulhall, director of the Male Sexual and Reproductive Medicine Program at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York, responds to readers' questions about prostate cancer.
docs.snippet: Dr. John Mulhall, director of the Male Sexual and Reproductive Medicine Program at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York, responds to readers' questions about prostate cancer.

docs.lead_paragraph: A program that clusters homeless people into apartment buildings is rankling neighbors who say landlords are pushing them out because the city pays far more -- an average of $1,730 an apartment -- than rent-stabilized tenants.
docs.abstract: Also in Morning Buzz: a program to fight recidivism; a governor in running shorts; a doctor who charges uninsured patients $1,000 a year for services; and other headlines from local papers.
docs.snippet: Also in Morning Buzz: a program to fight recidivism; a governor in running shorts; a doctor who charges uninsured patients $1,000 a year for services; and other headlines from local papers.

docs.lead_paragraph: The chairman of the Federal Reserve on Tuesday tacitly endorsed President Obama's call for huge increases in spending and trillion-dollar deficits over the next couple of years, saying the economic crisis required aggressive action.

headline.main: Fed Chairman Backs Call for Higher Spending

docs.abstract: The chairman of the Federal Reserve on Tuesday tacitly endorsed President Obama's call for huge increases in spending and trillion-dollar deficits over the next couple of years, saying the economic crisis required aggressive action. Though the chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, did not endorse any of Mr. Obama's specific proposals, he echoed the president's call for [...]

byline.original: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS and JACKIE CALMES

docs.lead_paragraph: Yesterday was something of a trifecta for A.I.G.: the company announced a quarterly loss of $61.7 billion; the government said it would pony up another $30 billion for the company as well as ease the terms of its deal with A.I.G.; and the former A.I.G. chief executive Maurice "Hank" Greenberg announced he is suing his old company for securities fraud.
docs.abstract: Anger over the mega-insurer's role in its own spectacular collapse is plentiful and raw.
docs.snippet: Anger over the mega-insurer's role in its own spectacular collapse is plentiful and raw.

docs.lead_paragraph: The reason the federal government just rescued American International Group for the fourth time in six months with taxpayer money has a lot to do with a terrifying potential consequence of letting A.I.G. fail: the possibility of a run on on the insurance industry.

headline.main: The Other Big Risk at A.I.G.

docs.abstract: The reason the federal government just rescued American International Group for the fourth time in six months with taxpayer money has a lot to do with a terrifying potential consequence of letting A.I.G. fail: the possibility of a run on on the insurance industry. It's a little-discussed but highly unnerving aspect of the crisis at [...]

docs.lead_paragraph: By easing the terms of its $150 billion rescue package for the American International Group, the government is trying to buy time for the financial conglomerate to slim down and reinvent itself as a simple property and casualty insurer, with a new name, new faces in the boardroom and perhaps an initial public offering in its future, The New York Times Mary Williams Walsh writes.

headline.main: A Remake of A.I.G. Is the Goal of Rescue
